monogr.title: A Kean* Shave between "John Bull and Brother Jonathan"

projectDesc.p: The Historic Images, New Technologies (HINT) project aims to enhance description and discovery of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania's graphics materials and promote the linking and sharing of content among institutions and scholars. The project will result in an update to HSP's digital image viewer and an online digital history exhibit that will demonstrate the new viewer's capabilities and provide interpretive and contextual materials to encourage users to interact with historical images in new ways. This project was funded by a grant from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission's (NHPRC) Innovation in Archives and Documentary Editing program.

editorialDecl.p: This electronic file was created using manual keying following the recommendations for Level 4 of "Best Practices for TEI in Libraries" guidelines v3.0.
This xml file uses unique entity identifiers, media file identifiers, and collection identifiers in HSP's Digital Library, available at http://digitallibrary.hsp.org.

div.p: This political cartoon slams British actress and writer Fanny Kemble for criticizing American manners and habits. The cartoon also references British actor Charles Kean and novelist Frances Trollope for similar negative remarks about Americans. Fanny Kemble is depicted at the center of the cartoon, dressed in rags. Standing at right and holding her hand is John Bull (representing Great Britain), who asks Brother Jonathan (representing the United States), standing at left, to take her in. Brother Jonathan refuses. Both Brother Jonathan and John Bull make lengthy speeches with numerous quotes from Kemble's published journal.
A KEAN* shave, between "JOHN BULL and BROTHER JONATHAN," or, another return from John's "right bits of English brag!"

p.hi: _____* (Keen, "that cuts well.") see Letter abusing Americans!_____

div.p: Why you tarnal Crittur, it beats all natur to think how slick you work it; Ivum on pohagen and wood-chucks, I ben too long stuffing your hungry beggars and paupers, rotten gizzards, with Chouder and chum-fish out o' pity and compassion's sake, tho' I shou'dn't s'pose, sir, car'd a snap o my finger about the Varment, seeng you mout "trollope her over" to the Butler o' the house, to "wallop in an American hell-of-a coach; bumping, thumping, jolting, shaking," and "tumbling," as if the "Devil blew a hurrican at her back." (page 77) I guess it would be rather "slithery, odd and dauldrummish (page 195) if the "Finger glasses" stood the "jog and jumble, p 158" whatever Fan's carcase mout tho, sartain twou'd make the sarpent squirm about, and "pish, and pshaw" the hull time, (page 98) like "musquetos, so cantankerous!!" see Vol. 1. page 96

By goes Jonathan, but I be summut roight glad to zee thee, wi zo many Forrest's and Hill's to show, and zo ah bethouten a power o' zarving thee, we a bit o' a "twaddling p. 64)(" zort o' a hoozey, who be a main beggarish breed, o' the "Puddledock" fudge family (p. 16) loike, but dang it, she can "wallop, and shample (p. 131) about at a "shuffling, (p. 52) rollicking, (p. 149) mongrel pace," mongst the Yankees; for "nathless" thof she hath a main hack "and snivelling fancy, for a snuggery" situation to "dowdle and potter in, we damnable iterations (p. 63) about looking on "the moon shine, over bright waters, as still as death" (p. 76) when there be a "sloping lawn (p. 80) to be jumping, tossing, and rumbling over, as if the "Devil had toied a string to her legs, and jerk'd her out o' spite" (p. 27); yet we be no ways proudish about such flimsyish flirtish brats, for we hae un in froightful aboondance, seeing they thout o' "making a necessity wi roight strange bed fellows" (p. 76) "Oh! England! England!!!!"
"How I do loathe the stage! and these wretched rags—an actress, a mimicker, a sham, creature me. Oh Horror! Horror!" p. 16. How the codfish stinks!
The Yankees, stupid, ign'rant Asses! don't know the Use of, Finger Glasses!!!!
Sold by J. Akin, Lithographer, No. 18 Prune Street Philada.
